element_texts.text: Memorandum design with flowers and crescent--image

1898_ My visit to "the fair"_ May 30_ Pleasant but very cool_ Fred, Mary, Mr. Gookin & myself left home at 12:30 PM for the fair. Went on the cable to Monroe St. walked to Van_Buren thence by the IC_R.R. reached the grounds_ Passed through two buildings hastily, but concluded to spend the time in the Manufactures & Liberal Arts B'd'g_ Saw an exhibit of Vermont Marble on entering. Then a curios display of sewing silks put up by the Belding Co in the form of a steam engine. Cotton & wool fabrics from different states_etc In the exhibit from France we saw gilded furniture, tapestries

tapestries, fine laces court dresses artificial flowers &c? In the exhibit from Holland we saw some good Delft ware & other porcelains- and found a seat where we could rest awhile The exhibit from the Island of Jamaica consisted mainly of different kinds of hard woods- many preparations of Cassava Root - and a fine collection of ferns - also some native fruits and nuts many of the latter being of medicinal character. A kind of bark which resembles lace when pounded and of which many lovely articles are made- From India elaborate wood carvings, embroidery in gold thread &c From Japan- paintings wood carving & the most hideous masks in the world-

We were very pleasantly entertained for a while by Mr Douet?- Commissioner from the Island of Jamaica- From Vienna Austria we saw very costly and most exquisite glass ware- At 6 P.M- heard the chime of bells but as seats were few and far between- hastened our departure- A break in the Cable delayed us on our return- but we arrived safely at 8. P.M-

2nd visit June 7th warm with high wind south & disagreeable- Mary & I left home at 12-15 P.M- by the same route as at first- The long walk between the cars is very tiresome We first went to the Fine Arts B'd'g- where we looked for a while at the exhibit of paintings from Holland none of which seemed to me of especial merit- Thence to the Japanese Department where we found Mr Choyo who showed us much kindness and attention- A long tailed rooster in bronze is very fine also an Ourang Outang carved in wood- We saw some beautiful articles in lacquer work, some carved ivories, and two views of Fuji- one in a round frame- also a

painting of a Peacock- In the gallery above we saw some very elaborate and beautifully embroidered screens- also paintings and lovely vases- We then went with Mr Choyo to a Tea House built in their peculiar manner, and where we were served with a kind of tea- very green in color, but mild & pleasant to the taste- Some pink & white confections- were also brought us- which were laid on little bits of bark- Each one was presented with a small fan as a souvenir- We visited the Ohio State B'd'g which has several large pleasant rooms well fitted up- from thence to the Wisconsin Building- a comfortable place where we rested for a time. The next point of interest

was the Woman's Building in the gallery of which we saw some fine thread laces some valuable old fans &c all in cases- We then went to the Library where we had an appointment to meet Dr. Gale? of Rutland why disapointed us- In this room is a bust of Mrs Harriet Beecher Stowe- After waiting an hour we left for home and on reaching Monroe St found the cable broken again and we waited a half hour in the street- Reached home at 8. P.M much fatigued-

3rd visit- Weather fine in every way. Mary & I left home at 12/15 P.M Visited the California B'd'g first, which resembles in form one of the old mission houses. It contains a wonderful display of native fruits- and the various products made therefrom- Tall glass jars containing preserved fruits most tempting to the eye- There were also olives and many kinds of nuts- A large dome made of oranges and a tower composed of bottles of olive oil- All the fruit is remarkable for its large size and fine color- We saw a large and highly polished slab in the shape of a half circle, made from one of the large redwood trees- We went next to the Fine

Arts b'd'g where we first visited the Austrian exhibit. One large picture is striking though disagreeable, representing a fierce fight among one of the leading men of the nation which afterwards led to The thirty years war- One picture of children is very pleasing- A boy is peeling an orange while his sister who stands waiting before him has but little clothing- one stocking- and an apron- In the Italian Section we saw some fine Statuary- two figures of children are very good- One of a young boy with a pleasant face who is holding up a mouse and tantalizing a dog beside him. The other of a girl- holding two puppies in her arms, while the mother is barking

beside her fearing her offspring are being carried off. Many of the paintings are very good and some of the subjects are interesting.  In the Main Hall of the building we saw a statue of Lincoln in a reclining position and dejected attitude holding the emancipation proclamation in his hand - 
We went next to the Woman's B'd'g on the first floor of which we saw more exquisite embroideries - fine linen doilies, h'dk's [handkerchiefs], table cloths etc - There is some good china painting.  We saw an interesting collection of large dolls dressed to show the costumes of different nations and of various periods. Many fine and valuable fans are also shown.

We made a short visit to the Children's b'd'g where we saw the model nursery the play room - the little white cribs etc -
We left at 5 P.M. Mr Choyo accompanying us - The cable cars were so crowded that we were compelled to stand all the way which added much to our fatigue - We reached home at 7-30 -

4th Visit, June 15 - German American day
Lovely day - Left home alone at 2/20 P.M. went to the Bank where Fred joined me - We went first to the Japanese section on the Island where we were joined by Messers Takayanagi and Choyo. We looked into the Ho-o-den which contains a tea service some porcelain stands - and some very pretty lanterns - There are sliding panels and highly decorated walls - We then went to the Horticultural B'd'g - where we say many kinds of green plants and ferns - the stag horn fern which grows outside the bark of a tree is very curious Except some fine orchids

not many plants were in bloom - There were many kinds of cactii and a pitcher plant - which is a very strange and interesting flower - The damp atmosphere prevented a long stay in that place -   To the Transportation B'd'g we went next - and saw several old locomotives and one old coach which would carry six persons - The new Modern Engines are very fine specimens of mechanical genius.  They are from France England and America - There were also some very fine passenger cars - some two storied ones for street-car service - Some rail road ties of wood from Australia - (very durable) - rail-way appliances.

in great variety
Many kinds of Cannon were shown some of which were very ancient - also shells of great size and weight for bombarding - There were boats of various shapes and sizes - and wheeled carriages in endless variety.  We told a little ride on the elevated rail way - which gives a view of the many fair buildings - We saw a large mound made of a dark brown clay which represents the homes of the cliff dwellers - and a model of some of the ruins of ancient Yucatan - 
Made an attempt to get some supper and went to four restaurants - but failed in all - (poor management)
In the Agricultural b'd'g

We saw an Exhibit from British Guiana - Stuffed animals and birds - furs - feather ornaments & fans - and many specimens of hard woods of fine color and markings - 
In the Electricity b'd'g our stay was short - The dynamos are interesting but the many colored globes of light were too dazzling for my eyes - Fire works outside detained us a few minutes and we then hastened to reach the cars ahead of the crowd - No trouble in going home which we reached at 10-30-
We passed through the Mines & Mining B'd'g but only stopped to look at some huge blocks of coal -

5th Visit
June 21 - Warm day - 
Left home at 10 - A.M - went to Congress St where were took the Elevated road and reached the grounds a little before noon - We had our lunch in the Liberal Arts b'd'g - We then went to the Government B'd'g - where there is much of interest.  The decoration of the Rotunda is very good and has in the center a section of one of the Cal' Redwood trees of immense size - We saw a representation of the different modes of carrying the U.S. Mail from ancient to modern times - on horseback - on a sledge drawn by dogs - on wagons - cars & bicycles.  Some old fashioned stage coached were of interest - We saw a pavilion the ornamentation of which was elaborate and made of

different kinds of grain - Stuffed animals of many kinds - and great quantities of fish eggs also the hatching process - The War Department is interesting with large and small cannon Lay? figures representing Army officers of different rank - guns ambulances - army wagons and much of the necessary paraphernalia for destroying life and property.
We then had a long search for the Vermont State b'd'g A poor little affair of small interest - The French B'd'g consists mainly of a small enclosed park surrounded by a wide piazza - The walls of which were hung with many paintings - We saw a large number of curious photographs of criminals in a kind of rogue's gallery -

The German B'd'g is very elaborately ornamented both on the outside and in the interior - Once section represents a portion of a Church with fine stained glass and gorgeous furnishings - There are many German books & some pictures and furniture.  The decorated ceiling is very nice and one room has a tiled floor - Some chairs made a comfortable resting place for us and I had a pleasant chat with a N.Y. lady - a stranger whom I met there.
The Spanish B'd'g is very nice consisting of one large room which represents the architecture of the Board of Trade b'd'g in Madrid - We then went to the Liberal Arts B'd'y where we saw stoves cutlery & the Gorham exhibit

of fine silver & glass ware.  Tiffany's is much the same but he has besides a Roman catholic Chapel with gorgeous fittings and ornaments - The Knight Templar have a booth which contains some very beautiful robes which those high in the order wear.  We came home by the elevated  road & found some difficulty in boarding the over crowded cable cars - but reached home at 7 P.M.

6th Visit June 27
Left home at 8:30 A.M. A lovely day - We went first to the Mining building we saw some very novel & interesting machinery to be used in drilling - crushing,&c in the mines - There were immense blocks of coal from Indiana, Penn' & other States - A large exhibit of petroleum (from N.Y. & Penn') both in the crude and refined states A fine exhibit of Asbestos and Mica from Canada - Many specimens of gold as found both in nuggets & dust - in Cal' - Montana and other States - Pearls from WIs - & some beautiful Turquoise in its natural state from Arizona - There are gems of different kinds from some of the Southern States - Men were at work cutting

and polishing diamonds from Australia - There was also a fine collection of uncut gems from various parts of the world - Japan has a Exhibit of some of its Mineral productions in that building - From Russia there were blocks of salt which were smoothly cut and polished - and much resembled quartz or ice in clearness - From Wales we saw a nice Exhibit of tin in blocks sheets - strips &c From this country - Copper in bars, sheets & different sizes of wire some was deep red in color - Some petrified wood from Cal' was very beautiful when polished - Building stone of various kinds & from several states is shown - some from the new state of Washington - After lunch

We went into the Gallery of the Liberal Arts b'd' - where we saw a fine exhibit of the work of feeble minded children fro schools located in different states - and tables showing the progress of many - We saw work done by the blind and some of the methods for teaching them were of interest - Stuffed birds of brilliant plumage from Australia - Artificial flowers from France Stained glass from Vienna & America? - Statuary - Musical instruments &c- Some fine and curious furniture from Austria & a pope organ - this is on one side only -  We then went to the U-S- portion in the Fine Arts building One room contains some fine Statuary - There are many oil paintings some fine and

many of little merit.  They occupy several rooms.  There is quite a large loan collection & many of the pictures there are fine  After a little visit with Mr Choyo in the Japanese Department  we left at 4 P.M. - and without trouble reached home at 6 - tired but satisfied with what we had seen and learned on this day - 
The silver statue in the Mining b'd'g said to be modeled from Ada Rehan's form is not very pleasing to me - though it represents labor and money.

7th visit
June 30 - Left home at 12.20 - It began to rain before we left the cable and caused some discomfort although it was only a shower - The grounds were wet and muddy - so we went at once to the Fine Arts B'd'g where we spent the greater part of the time - The French Section contains some fine paintings - but some of the nude pictures had better have been covered - Some noticeable ones are Don Juan in Hell - The death of Archimedes and portraits of President Carnot & of Pope Leo XIII - Rosa Bonheur's King of the Forest
&c-- We went again to the California b'd'g and as they have an elevator went easily to the gallery.

There are many water-color paintings representing the Flora & one very interesting picture called My Wife's loves but really represents numerous cats & kittens - There is a picture Gallery which we had not time to visit -  Then we went to the Wis' [Wisconsin] State b'd'g where Mr Choyo joined us and we had our evening lunch - Good water is not obtainable on the grounds - and there is always suffering from thirst.  We walked to the Manufacturers b'd'g - but it was not very well lighted - The exhibit from Siam was very pleasing - Immense Elephant tusks - fine Metalwork - porcelains - musical interments - boats &c -Left at 7 & reached home without difficulty -

8th visit
July 7 - Very warm day
Left home at 9-30- A-M- Went by the usual route - Passed through the Mining b'd'g where we saw some fine large blocks of greenish col'd stone in which were veins of Asbestos some three inches in thickness 
There was also a fine Exhibit of Mica
Some jewelry was interesting composed of brilliant blue moonstones from Brazil - A revolving] machine for washing ores was of interest to us - We went to the Liberal Arts b'd'g to eat our lunch and afterwards into the Gallery - where we saw optical & surgical instruments of many kinds and for varied uses - plaster casts for the instruction of students of surgery - and an immense quantity of pills

probably unmedicated
over 3,000,000 in a large glass case - There were pillets and tablets of all sorts and kinds very skillfully arranged and to be used for various ailments - A very nice way of preparing some medicines which are disagreeable to the taste!  Some fine pottery is there and some good specimens of China painting - Two articles were decorated by Miss Emma Cole of Catskill N.Y. a very interesting lady whom I met some years ago - She is a daughter of Thomas Cole a painter - once well known
The Roman Catholic Educational Exhibit is a large one - They have many pictures & pamphlets - and a statue of ArchBishop Feehan They also have a large library partly composed of books in

the French language which occupies three rooms-- At 3-30 we found a place in an unoccupied windowwhere we watched the arrival of the three Spanish Caravels. The Santa Marie Nina & Pinta accompanied by the U.S.Revenue Cutters Michigan and Andy Johnson and many other vessels- Of the procession which was formed later on we could see but a small part -- On the main floor we went to the Japanese section where we saw much fine pottery - funny masks rugs &c--We saw a beautiful display of kid gloves --hosiery &c in the French section.  Sypher & Co of N-Y- have a display of costly and highly ornamental furniture in the gallery-- The large dis-

--play of Bohemian glassware is pleasing - and some of the vases are very nice--- We suffered for want of drinking water which was not cold enough to be refreshing--  The extremely warm atmosphere prevented us from walking about very much and we left for home at 6P.M-  which we reached without any trouble____

9th Visit - July 11 - Warm day - Fred Mary and I left home at 9 A-M - Mr. Silsby giving us a ride in his buggy down town---We stopped at Walker's store while Fred attended a business meeting and then proceeded to the Fair-  We directed our steps first to the Midway Plaisance.  In the "Cairo St" which is very narrow and paved with brick, we saw many strange people of different kinds - several camels and donkeys on which women and boys were taking short rides -- There was much crowding and cries of "look out".  We inspected the Ferris wheel but did not care to make the ascent when the sun was shining so fiercely.

Went into the Japanese village where there are so many copper colored little people, both men women and children- Their houses are made of bamboo cut in strips and woven in basket fashion.  They have thatched roofs and are built on raised platforms  We attended a performance at their theater- The room and seats are comfortable and the music by native musicians not inharmonious.  They sit cross legged on benches or platforms and wore red turbans and a kind of blouse of the same color - They have instruments with one string. on some they use a bow and on others a kind of hammer also a mallet-  They ended by playing "America & "Yankee Doodle". The play was

mostly a pantomime representing the Creation.  Some of the girl actresses had very pretty features and were graceful in movement-  Outside they were weaving a kind of fine cotton in plaid of bright coloring. and on small hand looms - One woman was slowly painting a geometrical pattern on cotton cloth - some were braiding hats of straw - Two little dark skinned children were very cunning - We had our dinner in the German Village - a fair meal and big price - We visited some of the bazaars - where they have many article for sale but none were very attractive. We were much dissapointed in our visit to the American Glass Works---

A pleasant ride on the Elevated Toad took us to the Forrestry b'd'g -  where we saw numerous specimens of hard woods suitable for manufacturing and for building purposes - The exhibit from Brazil is especially large and fine- Two of the commissioners made it very pleasant for us- We saw an odd kind of rope made from a woody fibre very strong, also some dried leaves from a shrub of lovely shades of brown, and which resembled velvet & satin in appearance - We went next to the Shoe & Leather b'd'g where beautiful specimens of leather for various purposes are shown -  Very delicate kinds for making gloves book covers - boxes &c - There are boots & shoes for hot & cold climates and for

various occasions - some specimens of furs are shown.  We then went to the movable sidewalk on which we rode around twice very pleasantly - thence to the pier where we went aboard the Whale back steamer Columbus and had a most delightful ride on the lake as far as Van Buren St-- From there we took the long walk to the cable cars and reached home at 9 o/clock---

10th visit July 19- Nice comfortable day Left home at 9. a.m- and went by the usual route. To the Fine Arts Building we first directed our steps- Visited one room belonging to the Russian Exhibit- It contains some very good paintings 2 marine pieces are especially so- One represents the Santa Marie (with Columbus on board) in a storm- A ray of sunshine from a rift in the clouds, gives hope to the mariners and adds much to the beauty of the picture, shining as it does over the almost overwhelmed vessel- We found our way next to the exhibit from Great Britain which contains the largest collection of good pictures which we have seen as yet-

An attempt to describe them all here would be impossible- We stopped for a while in the rotunda and main entrance way of the b'd'g- to look at some pieces of statuary which are fine and of much interest- We then had a long walk to the Liberal Arts Building where we ate our lunch- and could get some good coffee- There are but few places where anything fit to eat or drink can be obtained at a reasonable price- We again passed through the Government b'd'g and spent some time in looking at the models of various kinds of machinery- They are beautifully made and kept in glass cases for protection against rough handling- Our next visit was to the Fisheries b'd'g- where we saw many

specimens of the finny tribes some familiar and some strange indeed- One large crab with a yellow covering 12 inches across, and resembling an up-turned saucer is very curious- The creature has several claws- and a tail some eight or nine inches long- and the abdomen made with flaps which have propelling power- There were spotted trout lovely gold & silver fishes- some gold with black stripes- Also some extremely thin fish & many curious kinds Another room contained boats nets, spears, and fishing tackle of all sorts and kinds- We then winded our way to the Woman's b'd'g- in the Gallery of which we saw an exhibition of the work done by the women of Japan. Some

embroidery screens, paintings &c- The women of Cincinnati have finished a room in this gallery very nicely- It contains furniture finely carved by women- and two cases containing- some good examples of painting on porcelain- There are books pictures &c- In one department on the first floor we saw many beautiful specimens of thread laces- some nice curtains- silk embroideries for Church vestments and one elaborate white satin gown made by a Chicago Modiste We saw several devices in the shape of utensils for saving of labor in household work We saw a woman from Scotland who was weaving on a hand loom a kind of checked woolen cloth and another one was carding
wool by hand and making it into rolls- ready for spinning We left early on account of the large crowd- and reached home at 5-30 P.M.

11th visit July 29th- Nice day- Left home at 9 A.M. by the usual route- Went to the California b'd'g first and into the picture gallery which is up stairs- The paintings are of no unusual merit- though of some interest- We then went to the Colorado State bg- where there is a good display of minerals- and some fine specimens of petrified wood which takes a fine polish and resembles variegated marble- The South Dakotah b'd'g is much the same but smaller- The new State of Washington has a large b'd'g and a fine display of fruits of various kinds well put up- and many examples of grain in bags large & small- There are models of farming implements and

machinery- stuffed animals (deer & elk) the skeleton of a mastodon finely mounted and some birds- The Louisiana b'd'g- is cool and comfortable- and we found there the first good drinking water- We then went to the Fine Arts b'd'g- where we stayed some time- The exhibit of paintings is very good and occupies four rooms- from Belgium- I should have said- The notable pictures we have marked in the Catalogue- We then went again into the British galleries to look longer at some of the finest pictures Many of them require very careful study- I was much impressed by one called broken Idol- and one of young Christian maidens about to

be devoured by Lions_ There are some very fine portraits and many good water color paintings_ _ We went upstairs to see the Bronze Falcons brought over by Mr Hayashi
which we greatly admired_We met there a Japanese gentleman who gave us an opportunity of examining a wonderful embroidered screen It represents the four seasons and is valued at $20-000 We ate our lunch comfortably under some trees_ And had coffee in the Costa Rica b'd'g_which we inspected later_ It has silks_ stuffed birds_mountains and caves represented with animals_ the tapis among them_ native fruits, coffee and plants_ Guatemala has a similar b'd'g though smaller_ has coffee peas

and beans of various kinds
specimens of hard woods &c?_
The Venezuela b'd'g is much
the same_ The Turkish b'd'g has
very elaborate outside ornamentation
brown in color_
Inside there are silks jewelry,
inlaid chests and stools
scarfs shawls and textile fabrics_
A marine torpedo and
small fire engine_ In the
India b'd'g tea is served
free and is very good_ There
are rugs in great variety
highly ornamented brass
utensils, old pottery_ Idols
textile fabrics_ And several
kinds of tea in cases_
We then passed through the
Transportation building on
our way home_ And again
admired the fine carriages
of all sorts and kinds, some
very heavy French vehicles_

elegant sleighs &c We also went through the Horticultural b'd'g_ And saw plenty of green plants and vines and but few flowers_ The Cactus tribe is well represented_ There are
many curious kinds both large and small_ Spain has a very large wine exhibit in this building_ There is also a fountain and an artificial cave here_ We had no trouble in getting seats in the cars_ And reached home at 6-30 - feeling that the day had been well spent_We also visited the Penn b'd'g where we saw the old Liberty Bell_

12th Visit
Aug 2_ Warm day_Left home at 9_A-M and went by the usual route. We first wandered into the Plaisance_ as far as the Bedouin encampment_ They have a fountain in the centre of the enclosure_ And the representation of a palace at one end_ It has cushioned seats against the walls_ carpets and hangings_ We saw the strange manner of bread making_ Two of the girls danced to the beating of a drum by the hands of a woman and a kind of wind instrument played by a man_ One of the girls would have been pretty had she been neatly dressed They do not seem to be very cleanly in their habits_The glare of the white sand on the walks at the Fair is

is very trying to the eyes_We went for a little time into the Woman's b'd'g_ Saw among other paintings one by Marie Bashkirtseff_ (two little boys Pierre & Jacques) good work_ The embroideries and fine laces again claimed attention and we saw a magnificent point lace shawl sent by the Queen of Belgium. We ate our lunch under some trees on the Wooded Island and then wended our way to the Liberal Arts b'd'g_ Spent some time in viewing the magnificent display of gems by Tiffany_A large yellow diamond valued at
100-000$ is made to revolve so as to display it to good advantage_ There is much fine silver ware_ watches_ and valuable jewelry_ The German Section near by is very fine
And a fountain in the center

makes the place more attractive_ They also show diamonds and much fine jewelry_ There are also porcelains, textile fabrics_yarns_ embroideries &c . A display of highly ornamental clocks from London kept us for a while_ And an exhibit of Doulton ware_ Many of the pieces were finely decorated and graceful in shape_A case of Ladies dresses from Paris was of some interest_And we stopped to examine a gas range in working order_ We then went to the Art Galleries_ Germany has five rooms and some good pictures_
"Polyphemus fishing"_& "Salome the Daughter of Herodius" are striking examples_ Spain has two rooms only_ Most of the paintings are old and of large size_

Many others from both countries are good_ We looked at a few pieces of sculpture on our way_ After chatting a few minutes with Choyo we started for the cars? A b'd'g
called Merck is a Pharmacy_It is very nicely decorated and fitted up in the interior_We reached home at a little past 6 o/clock_
Fred's birth day & he spent it by ascending Killington Peak near Rutland_

13th Visit_
10_ August_ Hot south wind
and extremely warm_ 94°_
Left home at 9-30 and went
as usual by the cable and
I.C.R Road -  Our first stop
was at the Fine Arts building
where we studied some pieces
of Italian sculpture for a time
and then looked at the Austrian
Exhibit of paintings_ And also
those by the Society of Polish Artists,
which occupy but one room_
Some good pictures are in both
exhibits_ We spent an hour
then left for the Liberal Arts
b'd'g_ On our way passed through
the unclear- b'd'g - again_ Stopped
awhile to rest, and looked at
some life-size figures of Indians
in native costume_ We ate
our lunch in the middle aisle
of the large b'd'g_ And I talked
awhile with a pleasant lady
(a stranger) from Syracuse N.Y.

While sitting in that place
the Rajah of Kapathala passed
by with a part of his suite_ He
has good features and looks like
an intelligent man_ _ We had
some coffee at the Wellington lunch
counter and met there a Southern
lady who was very indignant
that a colored man should be
allowed to eat with white people_
We then resumed our tour of inspection
and saw a model bathroom_
with floor of white tiles_ &
marble wainscot_ porcelain tubs,
one for adults_ the other for children
shower bath with rubber curtain
wash stand_ and other fixtures
in sanitary style_
We also looked at some nice
improved refrigerators from
Quincy Ill_ And passed on to
the French Section_ Where we
were lost in admiration of the
fine display of porcelains_

very delicate ware and finely
decorated_ The bronze
figures are very good_ and
in great variety_ A large
case is filled with travelling
clocks_ another with watches
and jewellry_ Some fine
cutlery is also shown_ pearl
handled knives &c_ There
are two cases of costly dresses
for ladies_ one for evening
wear and one for day-time.
Hats and bonnets are there
too - Silks &c
We were much interested in
the Russian exhibit which
is large and costly_ There are
many valuable furs_ three large
stands filled with boas_ skins
of the silver and blue fox, and
sable_ There are chairs covered
with fur which were not very pleasing_ fur rugs
with animal heads &c

There was silver ware jewelry - unmounted gems enamelled spoons of various sizes - cut glass - porcelains in which they do not excel or in their embroideries-
Norway exhibits among other things - home made carpets-a kind of vehicle with two wheels  snow shoes - furs - & one nice row boat --  The Swiss exhibit is very interesting - consisting mainly of watches and jewelry, and beautiful wood carving - There are figures of animals of many kinds - and models of Swiss cottages- Their work is all finely done - A charming Hall tree or Hat rack is shown - A bear is represented as hugging the lower part of an old tree on which at the very top her cub is complacently perched --  We saw a fine

display of Oriental rugs some from Marshall Field's collection and from other exhibitors who live abroad - We again went into the Japanese section where many improvements and additions have been made - There are beautiful gold lacquered boxes  carved ivories - and no end of porcelains - from thence we wended our way to the terminal station where we took the cars for home - they were uncomfortably warm - & the long walk tedious - The cable cars were much crowded and were obliged to stand nearly all the way home.  We arrived at 6-30-

15th visit        August 22 - Left home at 9-30 and went by the direct route. The day comfortably cool - To the Fine Arts b'd'g we directed our steps and ascended to the upper galleries by a long flight of stairs - Some pictures there by Sweedish artists are good - Some etchings by Zorn are shown- there is a good portrait of 
Ernest Renan- by him -  There are original drawings for the Century Magazine which are interesting -  Mexico sends some large and striking pictures -  A good many by American Artists are hung in this part of the building -  We went to the Japanese section where Mr Satoh showed us some exquisite cloisonne enamel vases - there are three  - one pink and one blue - and the most costly one is green.  There are many

others which are fine -  We ate our lunch under some trees near the Costa Rica b'd'g and went to the Ceylon b'd'g for some tea which was much too strong to be good-  There are three buildings in the exhibit -  1 of quite good size.  The Singalese people are black but fine looking= The men wear the hair long and in a coil with a comb to hold it back -  We had a peep at a baby in their pavillion with its mother  They exhibit tea, coffee, hard woods - some embroidery- wood carving - baskets &c. The New South Wales b'd'g contains a picture gallery only some of the paintings are good   They also show a bust of Sara Bernhardt -  and one of the Actor John Dillon --  The Haytien b'd'g is very

pretty on the exterior and full of interest in the interior -  We saw a sword once carried by Touissant L'Ouverture -  some very nice furniture made from native mahogany -  and a reed organ made by an ingenious man who had to use very odd materials in its construction.  Old metal spoons for reeds &c -- Norway has a very small b'd'g but nicely constructed - with good wood work extending to the top of the open roof - no plaster -- We then passed through the Liberal Arts b'd'g and stopped to look again at the German exhibit of fine laces, jewelry, cloths - silks - and some carved furniture -  We went into a Coal? port pavillion where we saw some very fine porcelains - and a beautiful vase which was presented to Queen Victoria on the occasion

of her jubilee -  and again admired the exquisite glass vase from Vienna --  We visited the Victoria House  It contains two large rooms with fire places - Wilton carpets some comfortable looking uphostered furniture and an armchair carved by the Princess of Wales - There are large book cases - covering two sides of one room and filled with books, which are kept out of the reach of visitors - it is no more elegant than many Chicago homes -  We went into the rottunda of the Administration building which did not impress me as some of the other b'd'gs have done -- We then went to a seat near the basin where we had nice fresh air - but vainly

waited for procession of boats which did not appear - We then proceeded to the gallery of the Mining - where we obtained a position by a window and saw a review of the U.S. Cadets from West Point - and heard some good music by a military band.  We were surrounded by a group of nuns in their hideous costume but they talked pleasantly and seemed to enjoy the sights --  We returned to the main b'd'g for our evening meal and rested awhile -  then stayed a while in the gallery -  We saw many boats on the lagoon very gaily decorated with lanterns and electric lights - which presented a very gay appearance -   We saw in the afternoon some fine blooded horses led by their groom for exercise -  The great gathering of so great a number
of people was a fine sight.  And generally a well behaved crowd --  We left at 8:30 and had no difficulty in getting aboard cars --  We reached home just before 10--

16th visit.     24 August - Illinois day - very warm.  Left home early, early before 8.A.M. and reached the grounds soon after 9 - We hoped to secure seats where we could comfortably view the parade of the strange people from the "Plaisance" but the crowd were ahead of us and we were obliged to stand for an hour and a half in the hot sunshine- or give up what we mainly cared to see -  Finally through the kindness of two gentlemen (strangers to me) who helped me to stand on a very narrow space at the end of a settee- not more than three inches in length- I was enabled to see fairly well - There were Turks Arabs - Soudanese - Dahomey's Amazons, Bedouins, South Sea Islanders - Singalese Javanese and North American

Indians in their war paint whooping and shouting-  There were some Chinamen - Some were mounted on camels some on horses on donkeys and many on foot.  Their music was wild and strange but not unpleasant - All were in Gala Attire -- Probably such an assemblage of people from the remote parts of the earth will never be seen together again - by most of us at least- We then went to the main b'd'g  where we watched the passing of the Illinois State Troops (5000 men) Infantry - Cavalry - Artillery - with several pieces of ordinance -  We were again obliged to stand and were much fatigued but some nice coffee at the Wellington Lunch Counter refreshed us

and found a comfortable place for eating our lunch in the middle aisle of the b'd'g - -  Afterwards went to a pavilion occupied by an exhibit from Wirtunberg Germany  -  A painting is on one side representing a street in the old part of the city and a portion of the Cathedral -  The canvas is very large and quite interesting.  A good many scientific instruments are shown - Further on we saw some very nice chairs exhibited by a firm in Pearl St New York  (Kohu). The exhibit from Venice occupies a large floor space and is mostly filled with carved furniture  There are many objections to using articles with much carving in this dusty and

smoky city -  The chairs before mentioned were more pleasing to me and finer in design - Comfort is to be sought first by sensible people who are purchasing furniture!We saw many fine dinner sets - vases jardiniers &c shown by N-Y-  firms-  some with dark blue decorations were very pleasing -  A short shower which extended only over a small area made the grounds muddy and we thought best to leave early.  We stopped at Walker's store on our return and reached home at 2,-30--

17th visit. August 26 -  Nice day - Left home alone at 1-30P.M. and went to the Bank where Fred joined me and we started for the Fair -  We saw a large procession of unemployed men some 6000 or more who were just starting to parade the streets headed by a brass band - A bad, rough looking set of men - and I saw an element of danger.  They should not be allowed to gather in such numbers - They became riotous later on  -- but were suppressed by the Police - We spent nearly all of the scribed correctly in the Liberal Arts b'd'g  Inspected the Mexican exhibit  They show some very fine onyx slabs, one was 5 feet square - We again

visited the Venition section - They have some good porcelains and the glass ware is very fine and of much interest -- Mexico has a display of sombrero hats very heavy and uncomfortable to wear I think   some hammocks, and some very gay embroideries - We again visited the Denmark exhibit with pleasure -- It  contains many articles of terra cotta ware - finely decorated some hand painted - The vases I admired greatly.  A kind of blue grey vase was more pleasing to Fred.  We stayed awhile among the heaps of pottery from Japan and then climed the stairs leading to the gallery - I was suffering so much from a cold that

I left most of the sight seeing to Fred -- We started just before six in search of a respectable restaurant, but came to the conclusion that the fare is very poor in all of them - and prices high.  In consequence of a broken cable when we reached Dearborn and Monroe Sts we had to walk over Clark St bridge making a long journey of three miles for me, and fatigued me greatly.  We reached home about 9 o/clock

18th Visit - 21 September -- Very warm with high south wind.  Fannie & I left home at 9 A.M.  by the usual route and after reaching the grounds went first to the Fine Arts B'd'g-. After looking at the statuary in the Fine Arts Building (the rotunda portion) we went into the U-S- Section and tried to see some of the pictures in the Loan Collection but the great surging crowd made it nearly impossible   These are many paintings by noted foreign Artists in the two rooms -  The heated atmosphere shortened our stay -  and we walked over to the battleship (Illinois)   We inspected the main deck but the wind and heat prevented

us from either going upon the upper deck or down below - We then went in search of a comfortable place for eating our lunch. - We found chairs near the Ceylon tea house and obtained a cup of the beverage served there - It was not very good however --  We then walked in a gale of wind to the Main b'd'g which we found somewhat more comfortable -  We saw there four model bathrooms - tubs - bowls - sinks for dish washing - &c. Also a new kind of bath tub which could be lifted up and enclosed in a case like a folding bed - A Pittsburg Co furnishes them --  We again went into the German and Italian sections where there is much to admire - 
We saw many beautiful silks

of both American and foreign weaves - also a fine display of braids & other dress trimmings --  An Indian wigwam was somewhat attractive - as it was furnished in the usual manner of savages and was so constructed that it could be quickly taken down and moved by their ponies --  We looked for a while at some fine porcelains --  but the oppressive atmosphere hastened our departure and we left at 4 reaching home a 5-30 --  A heavy shower came up in the evening -- and was very welcome - the first rain in 94 days --

19th visit
Sept 26 - Pleasant + very cool. Left home at 9.15 am. with Mina + Mary. Went by the usual route to the terminal station. Thence to the Administration building. where we we were soon joined by my brother William + son Willie. We decided to go to the main building. where we saw first some good pieces of Statuary from Rome Italy. We also saw the longest section of traction Cable ever made. After spending a little time on looking at the diamond exhibit by Tiffany we found seats and ate our lunch in the middle aisle, soon after we had a good cup of coffee at the Wellington. We then went to the Government building where I again looked over interesting exhibits previously seen. We went into an Army

Hospital where besides surgical instruments we saw fractured portions of human limbs that had been amputated and in some of which bullets were imbedded. In one the bullet was flattened by the contact of the bone. There were also human skills through which balls had passed. The cause of death was shown in various ways. From the Hospital we went to see the locomotive which has made the fastist time on record - No 999 - and manufactured in Albany N.Y. We also went through a train of passenger cats very elegantly furnished, and finished in the finest style known. Mahogany both red and white, satin wood + birch

were used for the wood work in the unclear. We then spent an hour + more in the transportation building where besides carriages from foreign countries we saw the largest locomotive in the world. A portion of an old Roman plank road built five years before the birth of Christ was of interest. An old tramway + switch made of wood on which was a battered car some three feet long by 18 inches wide claimed our attention. It was run on clumsy wooden rollers and used in Hungary in the 19th Century. Similar cars are still in use in some parts of that country. I met Mr R.M. Gardner who kindly gave me a chair and with

him had a very pleasant chat while waiting for the others to look about for themselves. As it was William's birth-day, we left the grounds early, and reached home soon after 5. P.M. I strained my ankle in getting on the cars, so that I suffered much pain for several hours afterwards

20th visit. Oct 2nd Left home at 8-30 with Mina. A damp foggy morning but warm, later on it turned to rain. Found William and Will waiting for us at the Liberty Bell, from there went to Machinery Hall, the largest upright boiler for evaporating water is there and oil is used for fuel. It's capacity to 1500 horsepower and has 10,000 square feet of heating surface. The largest Iron Plant ever made is 12 feet wide by 30 feet long. Cost 25,000 $. We saw a large travelling crane for moving heavy machinery to, which was very interesting, also the latest improved printing press, turning out several thousand pages a minute, printed on both sides of the paper and folded. A machine for making paper and showing it in all stages from the pulp to the finished article.

A loom for weaving ribbons of various colors, 16 at a time, but of the same width A machine for weaving gingham which ran with great rapidity, and one for weaving ingrain carpet, another, for embroidering thin fabrics, mostly handkerchiefs. A button-hole machine was very curious, doing good work and with great speed. We saw but a small part of the immense building in two hours. We went into the upper gallery, where we found comfortable seats for eating our luncheon. A heavy thunder shower came up while we were there. The rain prevented much outdoor walking so we spent the afternoon in the Transportation building. The largest locomotive weighs 284,220 pounds. We heard the music from a

a piano which plays automatically, and was more agreeable than most music made mechanically. In the gallery there is much of an interesting nature. We saw a model of a gaily bedecked hose and two wheeled vehicle from Syria. A figure of a native from India with a chair strapped to his back in which he carries travellers up the steep mountain sides. A large rough boat made of logs fastened securely together built and used NA Indians There were folding baby carriers, foreign made by unclear and those made in this country. We listened to the playing of the Iowa State Band for a half hour and enjoyed it very much. Muddy streets were disagreeable but we reached home at 5-20 + escaped another thunder storm.

The largest belt in the world is 208 feet long 8 1/2 feet wide, is three ply and weighs 5176 1/2 pounds. 569 hides were used in its construction, and made by the Page Belting Company. The tallest flagpole in the world 215 feet long and is in front of the Washington State building.

21st visit_  5 October_ A perfect day_ Fred & I left home at 8-15 and went first to the Bank for a few minutes thence to the Fair Grounds_ We took the Inter Mural train near the 60th St Station and not only had a pleasant ride but a good view of the mass of buildings We went to the Convent of La Rabida which we found greatly crowded_ Some old papers signed by Columbus were there_ and many paintings said to be old. Besides the building itself there was not much of interest to us_ and we were glad to leave the surging crowd_ There is an old rusty anchor in the building said to have been used on the Santa Marie_ _ We next went to see the Krupp Guns_ The machinery necessary to be used in the management of the largest

one was of much interest There were heavy iron castings some 9 or 10 inches in thickness the immense projectiles had passed nearly through some of them_ and one was broken apart by the concussion_ all were deeply indented and much injured_ We saw some very large_ long_ and beautifully made shafting to be used in the construction of steam vessels_ there were many guns of different sizes with their equipments which we admired We went to the Agricultural bdg where the products of foreign countries were of much interest to us_ There was an exhibit of Italian macaroni made in numerous forms_ and of  fine quality_ From Bangkok in Siam there was an interesting display of native

fruits_ Some kinds were curiously put up_ A kind of squash was cut in form of flowers of several kinds and preserved in syrup_ The rose apple is small and very pretty in appearance_ Citron preserved and pickled_ ginger and green nutmegs we saw_ Japan has an exhibit of food products_ Rice of different kinds_ tea coffee &c_ In the gallery we ate our lunch_ There is much of interest there also_ Many articles are given away there by firms who advertize in that way_ We went to a small bdg near the main one where we had a cup of cocoa_ We spent a little time in the Liberal Arts bdg_ Saw Tiffany's exhibit_ The crowd was very great Fred looked carefully at the stained glass_ and we both

admired the fine display of unmounted gems_ Beryl and Aqua Marines are favorites of mine_ In the German Section we saw some very beautiful irridescent glass ware_ We stayed awhile in the Japanese Section_ saw silks_and some quartz globes_ and looked at a few pieces of pottery_ We then went to the Woman's bdg where we met Mina in the library Fred left us to go to a reception at the Lexington Hotel_ and we waited in the lower part of the Woman's bdg and on the Piazza until his return some two hours_ later_ At 6-30 we started for the Midway_ After a long walk we entered the Old Vienna St_ a curious place_ making one feel far away from home

We had our evening meal under a tent and meantime enjoyed the playing of a German Band stationed near_ The Ferris Wheel illuminated we saw on our way and it presented a gorgeous appearance_ We went to the Chinese Theater were we were much amused by their feats of  juglery? _  and the play which represented scenes in the world's Creation_ Their modes of acting are very peculiar. The tones of their voices are very discordant & disagreeable, a kind of screech_ Their dancing is a kind of posturing The music like that of all Oriental Nations is crude and inharmonious_ We stayed much later than usual at the Fair and reached home at 11-30 I was not over fatigued_

22nd visit Oct 12_ Warm in the morning but a heavy fog came on at noon making every body very uncomfortable_ Left home at 8-30_ Mary Mina & I_ Passed through the California bdg as usual and went to the N- York State building which is one of the largest and finest of its kind on the grounds The staircase is wide with short steps, and very easy of ascent_ The Assembly rooms are large and tastefully furnished_ They contain some relics of old times_ some curious old inlaid furniture_ (very nice) pictures_ and some old warming pans_ We then went to the Fine Arts Bdg where we first greeted  ? _ then

went to the U-S. Galleries which were greatly crowded making it very difficult to see the pictures_ We stayed an hour and one half then, went to the lunch counter in the Fisheries which is a comfortable place for luncheon_ Mina left us there_ and we went to the Main bdg again Saw china fine glass and jewellry_ The bad weather hastened our return and we met Mina at the Terminal Station_ We had some difficulty in going home as the cable on Lincoln Ave'was broken and we had a longer walk in the mist than was agreeable. We reached home at 6_ P. M

23rd visit 17 October_ Mild and pleasant Fall weather_ Four of us left home at 8-30_ Mary May Graves_ Mina & I_ and went by the I-C R-R_ We went first to the Fine Arts bdg where we again saw the beautiful Falcons from Japan and the lovely screen_ The paintings in the Upper Gallery we found to be worth more study_ After a short stay there went down stairs_ saw one very pretty piece of sculpture (viz) the figure of a young girl sleeping in a Mother of pearl shell. We went to the Inter Mural Station where we took the cars for the south end of the grounds We lunched in the Dairy bdg not a very nice place. We saw butter moulded in ornamental forms_ some were

12 inches long and imitated boquets of flowers_ Large cheeses were shown also_ Mary & May left us and we passed through the Forestry bdg and went to the Gallery of the Anthropological bdg_ We saw many stuffed Animals_  A large and very fine collection of Corals some sea-shells_  and a beautiful collection of birds eggs of many kinds_ We saw two very old clocks_  one of them has a small pipe organ combined with it. We went into the room used for Psychological research and saw a gentleman who tried to be operated upon but evidently little effect was produced upon him. We then went to the Rumford kitchen to see the Atkinson oven & some other devices for saving fuel_ We were much dissapointed

in the utensils. Perhaps they were not fully explained to us_ The Cooking School we visited but saw nothing new_ In the Agricultural bdg through which we passed_ we saw in the Persian Section_ A large assortment of rugs_ one made of silk_  I saw none that were especially good in design_ There were some vases_ but only one of very pleasing design_ The jewellry was not especially good_ In the Japanese section we saw a rooster with a tail 10 feet in length He and a hen are in a  tall?  glass case_ and are stuffed of course The great crowds of people make sight seeing unpleasant now at the Fair_ We left a 4 and arrived at home at 5-30_

Bad weather & a cold prevented me from again visiting the Fair_ much to my regret_ On Nov 7th Mina_ my sister Emily & myself left home at 1 P M_ and went down to the Art Institute bdg to attend a flower show_ Chrysanthemums of all kinds and colors were in great profusion_ some of them of great size_ The white varieties were of great purity_ and are favorites of mine_ There was also a fine display of roses pinks_ and some orchids_ We enjoyed the afternoon and considered the time well spent_ Emily gave me a nice bunch of pinks_
